model_completion: Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, which is the muscular tube that runs from the throat to the stomach. The main cause of esophagitis is gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), in which stomach acid backs up into the esophagus, causing irritation and inflammation. Symptoms of esophagitis include heartburn, difficulty swallowing, chest pain, nausea and vomiting. Treatment for esophagitis depends on the underlying cause. For GERD, treatment typically involves lifestyle changes, such as avoiding certain foods and beverages that trigger symptoms and losing weight, if necessary. In some cases, medication or surgery may be necessary to treat GERD.

Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, the tube that connects the throat to the stomach. The most common cause of esophagitis is gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which occurs when acid and other contents from the stomach flow back up into the esophagus. Other causes of esophagitis include infection, trauma and ingestion of caustic substances. Symptoms of esophagitis include heartburn, difficulty swallowing and pain in the chest or upper abdomen.

Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, which is the muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach. The most common cause of esophagitis is acid reflux, but there are several other causes of this condition. Esophagitis can be diagnosed through a physical examination, endoscopy and imaging tests such as an upper GI series. Treatment for esophagitis depends on the cause, but it may include antibiotics, medications to reduce acid production in the stomach and lifestyle changes.

Other causes of esophagitis include infections, allergic reactions and medications.

Dysentery is a condition that causes inflammation and irritation of the intestines. The main symptom of dysentery is bloody diarrhea, but other symptoms may include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever and chills. People with dysentery usually feel very sick and need to be treated quickly.

Dysentery is a condition that causes severe diarrhea, often with blood in the stool. A person with dysentery may also have abdominal cramps and fever. The symptoms of dysentery are usually similar to those of other intestinal illnesses, so a health care professional will perform tests to determine the exact cause of the diarrhea and rule out other possible conditions.

Dysentery is inflammation of the intestine that causes severe diarrhea and abdominal pain. A bacterial infection is the most common cause of dysentery, but viral, parasitic or fungal infections can also cause it. The most common symptoms of dysentery include bloody stool, fever, abdominal cramping and a feeling of urgency to have a bowel movement. Treatment depends on the cause of the infection, but antibiotics are often used to treat dysentery caused by bacteria.

Dysentery is a condition that is caused by infection with the bacteria Shigella. Infected people can pass the bacteria on to others through contaminated food or water. People who have dysentery are most contagious when they have diarrhea, which can last for up to two weeks.

Dysentery is a condition that causes severe diarrhea, often with blood in the stool. In developing countries, it is most often caused by eating contaminated food or water. In developed countries, it is usually caused by eating undercooked meat or drinking contaminated water. People who are at risk of developing dysentery include those who travel to areas where there is poor sanitation and people whose immune systems are weakened by HIV infection or certain medical conditions.

Dysentery is an intestinal infection that can cause bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. The main cause of dysentery is the bacteria Shigella, which can be spread through contaminated food or water. To prevent dysentery, it's important to wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water, avoid eating undercooked meats or eggs, and drink only bottled or boiled water when traveling in areas where there is a high risk of infection.

Dementia is a general term that refers to a decline in mental ability severe enough to interfere with daily life. A person with dementia may experience memory loss, problems with language and difficulty carrying out familiar tasks. Dementia is not a specific disease, but rather a group of symptoms that occur when the brain is damaged by diseases such as Alzheimer's disease or a series of strokes.

Dementia refers to a group of symptoms that occur when the brain is no longer able to function normally. A person with dementia may experience memory loss, confusion and difficulty carrying out daily activities. There are several different types of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. Diagnosing dementia can be difficult, because the symptoms are similar to those of many other conditions. However, a doctor can often diagnose dementia through a combination of physical examination, medical history, neurological tests and brain imaging tests.

Dementia refers to a group of symptoms that occur due to damage to the brain. The most common cause of dementia is Alzheimer's disease, but there are many other conditions that can lead to dementia as well. Symptoms of dementia include memory loss, difficulty communicating and confusion. Treatments for dementia will vary depending on the underlying cause. In some cases, treating the underlying condition may help improve the symptoms of dementia. However, in many cases, dementia cannot be cured.

Dementia is a general term for loss of memory, language, problem-solving and other thinking skills that are severe enough to interfere with daily life. A common cause of dementia is Alzheimer's disease, but there are many other causes. Symptoms of dementia vary depending on the cause, but in general, people with dementia can have problems with memory, concentration, communication, planning and organizing, abstract thinking and reasoning, judgement, visual perception, orientation, learning, mood and personality.

Dementia is a general term that refers to a decline in mental ability severe enough to interfere with daily life. Risk factors for dementia vary, but there are several things that can increase a person's risk of developing this condition. These include age, family history and lifestyle choices such as diet, exercise and smoking. Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia, accounting for 60-80% of cases. Other types of dementia include vascular dementia, frontotemporal dementia and dementia with Lewy bodies.

Dementia is a condition that affects memory and thinking skills, and it can cause significant changes in behavior. The exact cause of dementia is not known, but it is often associated with aging. Treatments for dementia focus on slowing the progression of the disease and managing the symptoms. Some strategies for managing the symptoms of dementia include keeping a routine, engaging in social activities, exercising and using medications to treat specific symptoms.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils. The most common cause of tonsillitis is a bacterial infection, but it can also be caused by a viral infection or by allergies. Symptoms of tonsillitis include sore throat, fever, swollen tonsils and difficulty swallowing. If tonsillitis is caused by a bacterial infection, antibiotics can help treat the condition.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils that can cause severe throat pain and difficulty swallowing. A person with tonsillitis will typically have a sore throat, white or yellow patches on the tonsils, and enlarged lymph nodes in the neck. The most common cause of tonsillitis is a bacterial infection, but it can also be caused by viruses. In some cases, tonsillitis may be caused by an allergic reaction to foods, such as peanuts or shellfish. Tonsillitis is usually diagnosed through a physical examination and may be confirmed with a throat culture.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils. In most cases, tonsillitis is caused by a virus, and treatment focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing complications. However, if tonsillitis is caused by a bacterial infection, antibiotics may be necessary to treat the condition. Tonsillitis can cause sore throat, fever, headache, difficulty swallowing, bad breath and tender lymph nodes in the neck.

Tonsillitis is a condition in which the tonsils become inflamed. In most cases, tonsillitis is caused by a viral or bacterial infection and can be treated at home with rest, over-the-counter pain medications and gargling with salt water. However, some people are at risk for more serious complications, such as tonsillitis caused by strep throat. People who have had strep throat may experience recurrent tonsillitis, which is when tonsillitis occurs more than twice within 6 months. Recurrent tonsillitis can lead to scarring and other complications and may require surgery to remove the tonsils.

Tonsillitis is a condition that occurs when the tonsils become inflamed. In most cases, tonsillitis is caused by a viral or bacterial infection. Although there is no way to completely prevent tonsillitis, some measures can reduce the risk of developing this condition. Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection that can cause redness, pain and swelling. The affected area may also feel warm to the touch. The infection can spread quickly, so prompt treatment is important. People with diabetes or weakened immune systems are more likely to develop cellulitis.

Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and tissue just beneath the skin. The infection causes swelling, redness and tenderness in the affected area. Cellulitis can occur anywhere on the body, but it most often affects the lower legs and feet. Cellulitis is typically diagnosed based on symptoms, and a doctor may perform a physical exam to determine if the infection has spread to other parts of the body. Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and tissue just beneath the skin. The infection causes swelling, redness and tenderness in the affected area. Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and tissue just beneath the skin. Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection that can cause the skin to become red and swollen. The affected area may also be painful, warm, and tender. Vasculitis is a condition in which the blood vessels become inflamed, often leading to blood clots and tissue damage. Liver cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the liver. Liver cancer is the most common type of primary cancer, which begins in the liver. Liver cancer can occur at any age, but it is most common in people older than 50. Symptoms of liver cancer include yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice), pain or discomfort in the abdomen, weight loss, nausea and vomiting, fatigue and weakness.

Liver cancer, also called hepatocellular carcinoma, is often detected through blood tests and imaging tests. Liver cancer can be difficult to detect in its early stages because there are usually no symptoms. As the disease progresses, symptoms may include jaundice, abdominal pain, weight loss, nausea and vomiting. In some cases, a physical examination or an ultrasound of the liver may reveal signs of liver cancer.

Liver cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the liver. Liver cancer is the fourth most common cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States, and it can be difficult to treat. Bronchitis is inflammation of the air passages between the lungs and the trachea, which leads to coughing and shortness of breath. Bronchitis can be acute or chronic. Acute bronchitis usually lasts for only a few days and is often caused by viruses. Chronic bronchitis is a lung condition that involves inflammation of the airways for at least three months each year for two consecutive years. The main symptom of bronchitis is a cough that produces mucus. Other symptoms include wheezing and shortness of breath.

Cardiomyopathy is a disease in which the heart muscle becomes weakened, enlarged or stiff. The main symptom of cardiomyopathy is heart failure. There are many different types of cardiomyopathy. In some cases, the cause of the condition is unknown. Treatment will depend on the type of cardiomyopathy and its severity.

Cardiomyopathy is a disease in which the heart muscle becomes weakened, thick or stiff. The most common type of cardiomyopathy is dilated cardiomyopathy, which occurs when the ventricles of the heart become enlarged and weakened. Other types of cardiomyopathy include hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, in which the ventricle walls become abnormally thick, and restrictive cardiomyopathy, in which the ventricles are stiff. Cardiomyopathy can be caused by many factors, including genetic conditions, viral infections, alcohol use, high blood pressure and coronary artery disease.

Symptoms of cardiomyopathy include fatigue, shortness of breath, swelling in the feet or legs, and abnormal heart rhythms. There are three main types of cardiomyopathy: dilated cardiomyopathy, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and restrictive cardiomyopathy.

In some cases, a doctor may prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector, which is used to treat life-threatening allergic reactions.

Hives are the result of an allergic reaction. Stress would not directly cause the physical reaction of hives, but it may contribute to the development of hives. Individuals who have a family history of hives may be at a higher risk for developing this condition.

Hives caused by allergic reactions can last from a few weeks to a few months. The red, itchy bumps generated by an allergic reaction usually appear within minutes. A large allergy-related hive may be up to several inches in diameter and can cover most of the body.

Hives are a skin reaction that can be triggered by many things, including allergies, infections and certain medications. A person with hives may develop raised, red, itchy bumps on the skin that look like mosquito bites. These bumps can appear anywhere on the body, but they are most common on the trunk of the body and the face. People with hives should avoid the triggers that caused the condition, such as allergens or medications, to prevent flare-ups. In some cases, people with hives may need to take medication to control their symptoms.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness that causes flu-like symptoms, including fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, and a rash. A severe form of dengue fever called dengue hemorrhagic fever can cause bleeding, low levels of blood platelets, and even death. There is no vaccine for dengue fever, but it can be prevented by taking steps to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness that causes flu-like symptoms and can be fatal if left untreated. Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, which bite during the daytime, are the main carriers of dengue fever, and they spread the disease by feeding on infected humans and then biting healthy people. There is no vaccine for dengue fever, but taking measures to prevent mosquito bites can help reduce the risk of infection.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness that causes flu-like symptoms and, in severe cases, bleeding, shock, and death. The symptoms of dengue fever can range from mild to severe. Treatment of dengue fever involves supportive care, such as IV fluids, blood transfusions, and medications to control bleeding and reduce pain. There is no specific treatment for dengue fever, but early diagnosis and treatment can help prevent complications.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne illness that causes flu-like symptoms, and there is no vaccine to prevent it. The best way to prevent dengue fever is to avoid mosquito bites. People who are traveling to areas where dengue fever is common should take precautions to avoid mosquito bites, such as using insect repellent and wearing long sleeves and pants.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection that causes flu-like symptoms and, in severe cases, bleeding, shock and death. The disease is caused by any of four different types of dengue virus. Although there is no cure for dengue fever, prompt treatment with fluids and pain relievers can help alleviate the symptoms.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection that causes flu-like symptoms, including fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, and a rash. A person with dengue fever usually recovers within 2 to 7 days. In some cases, the virus can cause more serious complications, such as hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome, which can be fatal if left untreated. People who have been infected with dengue fever should rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take medications to relieve their symptoms.

Scleroderma is a condition that causes the skin and connective tissue to harden and tighten, leading to problems with blood flow and organ function. The symptoms of scleroderma vary depending on which part of the body is affected. People with scleroderma may have thickening of the skin, called sclerosis, and tightness in the joints, as well as digestive problems, kidney problems and lung disease. There are several types of scleroderma, including localized scleroderma and systemic scleroderma. Localized scleroderma affects only certain parts of the body and is usually not life-threatening, while systemic scleroderma can be more severe and life-threatening.

Scleroderma is a condition that causes the connective tissue in the body to become thick and hard, leading to problems with blood flow and organ function. The symptoms of scleroderma vary depending on which organs are affected, but often include skin changes, fatigue and joint pain. In some cases, scleroderma can be difficult to diagnose, as it shares many symptoms with other conditions. Diagnosis of scleroderma often requires a biopsy of affected tissue.

Scleroderma is a condition that causes the skin and connective tissue to harden and become tight, making it difficult for people with this disease to perform everyday tasks. The exact cause of scleroderma is unknown, but it is thought to be an autoimmune disease in which the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells in the body. There are several types of scleroderma, and the most common type is called limited scleroderma, or localized scleroderma. Treatment for scleroderma depends on the type and severity of the condition and may include medications, physical therapy, and lifestyle changes.

Scleroderma is a condition that causes the skin and connective tissue throughout the body to become hard and tight. The most common symptom of scleroderma is thickening of the skin on the face, hands and feet, but it can also cause inflammation of internal organs such as the kidneys, heart, lungs, esophagus and digestive tract. In addition to the thickening of the skin, scleroderma can cause joint pain, fatigue, Raynaud's phenomenon and changes in the eyes.

The cause of scleroderma is unknown, but it is believed to be an autoimmune disorder. Some people are more at risk than others for developing scleroderma, including those who have a family history of the disease and women who are over the age of 30. Symptoms of scleroderma can include Raynaud's phenomenon (which causes fingers to change color due to reduced blood flow), thickening of the skin and excessive scar tissue.

Scleroderma can also cause joint pain and Raynaud's phenomenon, which is when the fingers or toes become very cold and turn blue in response to cold temperatures or emotional stress. There is no cure for scleroderma, but treatment can help to manage the symptoms and slow the progression of the disease. Treatment typically involves medications to relieve symptoms and prevent complications.

Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare disorder in which the immune system attacks part of the nervous system. The most common symptom of Guillain-Barré syndrome is muscle weakness that typically starts in the legs and progresses to the arms and upper body. Other symptoms may include tingling, numbness and difficulty with balance and coordination. In severe cases, Guillain-Barré syndrome can cause paralysis.

Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare disorder in which the immune system attacks the nerves, causing muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis. The symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome typically develop over several days to weeks, and can vary depending on the severity of the condition. In mild cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome, symptoms may be limited to weakness in the legs, but more severe cases can cause paralysis that affects the whole body. Guillain-Barré syndrome is often difficult to diagnose because its symptoms are similar to those of other conditions.

Guillain-Barré syndrome is a condition that causes the immune system to attack the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis. The exact cause of Guillain-Barré syndrome is unknown, but it is thought to be triggered by an infection or surgery. Treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome includes intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), plasmapheresis, and supportive care.

Guillain-Barré syndrome is a neurological disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system. In Guillain-Barré syndrome, the immune system attacks the nerves in the body, causing muscle weakness and paralysis. Symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome can range from mild to severe and may include tingling or numbness in the extremities, muscle weakness in the legs, feet, hands, arms or face, and difficulty walking or standing.

The most common symptom is weakness and tingling in the legs, but it can also affect other parts of the body, such as the arms and face. The exact cause of Guillain-Barré syndrome is unknown, but it is thought to be triggered by an infection or immunization. People with certain medical conditions, such as diabetes, cancer, or HIV, may be at an increased risk for developing this condition.

Guillain-Barré syndrome is a neurological disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system. In most cases, this condition causes muscle weakness and paralysis, but it can also cause numbness, tingling, pain and other symptoms. People with Guillain-Barré syndrome are typically treated with corticosteroids and plasmapheresis (a treatment in which blood plasma is removed from the body). Lifestyle changes, such as eating a healthy diet and getting enough rest, may also help to manage the symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Acromegaly is a condition that occurs when the pituitary gland produces too much growth hormone. Growth hormone causes the body to produce excessive amounts of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), which leads to abnormal bone and tissue growth in the head, hands and feet. Acromegaly can occur if the pituitary gland becomes enlarged or if there is a tumor on the pituitary gland that causes it to produce too much growth hormone.

A person with acromegaly may develop enlarged hands and feet, thickened skin, a deepening of the voice, and an increased risk of diabetes and heart disease. Acromegaly can also lead to other health problems, such as high blood pressure and sleep apnea. The symptoms of acromegaly usually develop slowly over time, but can sometimes appear suddenly.

Acromegaly is a condition that occurs when the pituitary gland produces excess growth hormone, which can lead to enlargement of the hands, feet and face. A diagnosis of acromegaly is made after a thorough evaluation, which includes blood tests and imaging studies. In addition, the symptoms of acromegaly are specific and can be used to make a diagnosis. The most common symptom of acromegaly is an enlarged jaw.

A diagnosis of acromegaly is usually made through blood tests that measure levels of growth hormone and IGF-1, a hormone that stimulates cell growth. Treatment for acromegaly typically involves surgery to remove the part of the pituitary gland that is producing excess hormones. This procedure is known as transsphenoidal surgery. Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a common condition caused by an overgrowth of certain types of bacteria in the vagina. Epilepsy is a condition that causes seizures. A seizure occurs when abnormal electrical activity in the brain causes changes in movement, awareness and behavior. The symptoms of epilepsy vary depending on the type of seizure a person has. The most common type of seizure is a tonic-clonic seizure, which is also known as a grand mal seizure. During this type of seizure, a person's body stiffens and shakes, and they may lose consciousness. Other types of seizures include absence seizures, myoclonic seizures and atonic seizures.

There are many different types of seizures, and epilepsy can be caused by a variety of factors. Diagnosis of epilepsy requires an electroencephalogram (EEG), which measures electrical activity in the brain. Treatment may include medications, dietary changes, surgery and other therapies.

Some people may have seizures that occur with no known cause. Pleural effusion occurs when fluid builds up in the space between the layers of tissue that cover the lungs (pleura). The fluid can accumulate for many reasons, including injury or inflammation. Common causes of pleural effusion include pneumonia, pulmonary embolism and certain types of cancer. Symptoms of pleural effusion include shortness of breath, cough and chest pain.

Pleural effusion is a condition in which fluid builds up between the layers of the pleura, the membrane that covers the lungs and lines the chest cavity. Pleural effusion can be caused by several different conditions, including pneumonia, lung cancer, pulmonary embolism, heart failure and certain types of autoimmune disorders. Symptoms of pleural effusion include shortness of breath, coughing, chest pain and fatigue. Pleural effusion is typically diagnosed through a chest X-ray or CT scan.

Pleural effusion can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, fatigue, and fever. Pleural effusion can be caused by several different conditions, including pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, cancer, congestive heart failure, autoimmune diseases and infections.

Pancreatic cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the cells of the pancreas. Pancreatic cancer is a very serious disease and often has a poor prognosis. The symptoms of pancreatic cancer vary depending on where the cancer is located in the pancreas and how advanced it is. Common symptoms include jaundice, abdominal pain, weight loss and loss of appetite. Other symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, blood clots, and dark urine.

Pancreatic cancer is a serious disease that can be difficult to diagnose, as the signs and symptoms of the disease often do not appear until it has progressed. The most common symptoms of pancreatic cancer include abdominal pain, unexplained weight loss, jaundice (yellowing of the eyes or skin), loss of appetite and dark urine. A health care provider may suspect pancreatic cancer if these symptoms are present, but imaging tests such as CT scans, ultrasound or endoscopic ultrasound are usually necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Pancreatic cancer is a serious disease that can be difficult to treat, but there are several options available. Treatment depends on the stage of the cancer and whether it has spread. Treatment options may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of these treatments. Early detection and treatment are important in improving outcomes.

The pancreas is a long, flat gland in the abdomen that produces enzymes to help digestion and hormones to regulate blood sugar. Pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas. Symptoms include upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, fever, weight loss, diarrhea and jaundice.

Pancreatic cancer is a very serious and difficult-to-treat form of cancer. The cause of pancreatic cancer is unknown, but it is more common in people who have certain genetic mutations or who are obese. There are some things that can be done to reduce the risk of developing pancreatic cancer, including maintaining a healthy weight, avoiding smoking and limiting alcohol intake.
